text: hey guys I finally made it to my seventh
and final continent the coldest windiest
and driest place on our planet
Antarctica I can't feel my face
Antarctica is one of the most mysterious
and least visited places in the world it
only gets about 35,000 visitors per year
and I'm thrilled to have the opportunity
to visit on this amazing Hurtigruten
expedition we spent the last three days
on different parts of the continent and
I learned so much that I can't wait to
tell you can you tell how happy I am
here here are seven mind-blowing facts
about Antarctica one it was recently
discovered the existence of Antarctica
was completely unknown until the
continent was first spotted in 1820 and
the first explorer to reach the South
Pole was in 1911 - it's a huge desert
Antarctica is about 1.5 times the size
of the USA and it's surprisingly a giant
desert it might not appear that way
since everything is covered in white but
some parts haven't had rain or snow for
the last two million years three less
humans more animals Antartica has never
had an indigenous human population but
there is an abundance of wildlife like
penguins leopard seals and birds the
Penguins are such fascinating and cute
animals and I was surrounded by
thousands of them at all time I could
watch them for hours and hours and never
get bored for it's the coldest place on
earth Antarctica is the coldest and
windiest place on earth the annual
average temperature is minus 58
Fahrenheit or minus 50 Celsius and the
lowest temperature ever recorded was
minus 128 degrees Fahrenheit or minus 89
Celsius the water in the Antarctic Ocean
is between one Celsius and minus 1.5
Celsius and if you're lucky you can spot
the rare ginger penguin washing up
ashore oh five more ice and you can
imagine 90% of the
the height and fresh waters in
Antarctica some ice sheets are more than
four kilometers thick and others have
been in existence for more than 40
million years if all the ice in
Antarctica was melted it would raise
global ocean levels by 65 meters or 213
feet six civilizations do exist small
non permanent civilizations can be found
in Antarctica and they look like this
they're usually for scientists
researchers and photographers who camp
out for months in small settlements
we're inside one of the houses walking
around where they sleep think that'd be
a cold life 7
there's no time zone Antarctica is the
only continent without a time zone but
when you're here time is the last thing
on your mind
in the summer months it stays light
outside 24 hours a day and in the
wintertime it's the exact opposite this
trip to Antarctica is truly the best
travel experience of my life
and I couldn't possibly recommend it
more to anyone watching this video I'm
drew pinsky and if you liked my travel
videos please click Subscribe and join
